title: SUS: the Student UFO Society
description: During my first two months at Yale, I’ve learned how to be an indulgent skeptic. The Thursday before Family Weekend, I ...
article_content:
During my first two months at Yale, I’ve learned how to be an indulgent skeptic.

The Thursday before Family Weekend, I received an email advertising an 11-hour-long teach-in about UFOs, to which I responded with immediate incredulity. I wasn’t quite sure that “free exchange of ideas surrounding a challenging subject” could apply to government cover-ups of UFOs, a conspiracy theory seemingly on par with the flat Earth.

I decided to reach out to Sydney Morrison ’25, the leader of the Yale Student UFO Society, or YSUS, to find out what could lead a Yale student to believe that little green men in flying saucers were anything but pure science fiction. After a few back-and-forth emails, she explained her reasoning over lunch last Monday.

Sydney’s story with ufology, the study of UFOs, began during her time away from Yale after her sophomore year. Throughout her childhood and teenage years, her idea of UFOs was much like mine: “potentially some weird spiritual thing, like a semi-religious phenomenon.” But one night, while hanging out with a friend in a Washington park, they turned around simultaneously to see a large object with blinking lights in the sky. Unbothered at first, they then encountered an 8-foot-tall bulky humanoid object with two deer-like eyes, casually strolling around and absorbing all visible light entering its body. Sydney said that they got within two feet of the alien, which continued to stomp around and followed them back to their car.

Naturally, this experience was “pretty shaking,” and Sydney started YSUS her next semester back at Yale to create a space for UFO believers — the only such space in the Ivy League. The club’s main goal is to consolidate and present knowledge on UFO sightings.

Convincing those in the Yale community is more of a secondary objective. Sydney explained that when talking about her experience to people outside the ufology community, she always begins with “I know this sounds crazy” or “I wouldn’t have believed it myself,” but it’s often unsuccessful; she’s mostly given up on convincing people to believe.

“There’s such pervasive stigma that associates UFOs with mental illness,” she told me. “It’s scary when you do try to take [beliefs about UFOs] further into the media and the public.”

I felt sympathetic to her cause. If UFOs were to exist, I — and most of the world — would be virtually clueless, having been deaf to all those who claimed to have seen evidence. Sydney often wishes she hadn’t had her sighting — “it’s kind of like the Matrix, where you can’t go back after you’ve seen something like that,” she said. Personally, I’d rather live my life unaware of any alien existence — I can’t imagine being so utterly sure of a truth that my family and friends would never accept.

Curious about what led other students to join the club — to voluntarily take the red pill — I talked to Lorenzo Chamberlin ’28, YSUS’s newest officer. He told me that he saw a poster advertising YSUS on the way to class one day and was immediately drawn to it. He’s never had an experience with UFOs, though he would like to, and was enthusiastic about the club’s efforts to find “ways to have those experiences.” He quoted Sherlock Holmes to summarize his reason for joining: “once you’ve eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.”

It turns out that Lorenzo wrote the original teach-in email that piqued my curiosity. Rereading it after our chat, I realized that his description of the event’s purpose — raising awareness for “wider epistemological challenges to accepted boundaries of scholarship and civic activism” — was not a half-baked attempt at intellectualizing a joke but a genuine reflection on how deep our assumptions lie.

Over the course of our lunch, Sydney presented a logical, well-thought-out argument. By the time she brought up postcolonialism and ontology, it was clear that she’d spent hundreds, if not thousands, of hours researching ufology.

We talked for around an hour, but most people don’t devote that much time to understanding a claim viewed as fundamentally absurd. It’s so easy to just dismiss someone as crazy when that’s what the rest of the world thinks.

In my philosophy and astronomy courses, I’ve learned about dozens of breakthroughs that were met with universal skepticism when they were first made. Ideas like philosophical questioning, the heliocentric theory and special relativity were incredibly controversial when proposed because they disrupted beliefs that felt safe and secure. Socrates, Galileo and Einstein — some of the most important contributors to human knowledge — were all shunned for their “radical” and “preposterous” findings.

So maybe — however unlikely — UFOs are real and Sydney is the next Einstein. I’m not quite convinced, but I’ve learned to at least give everyone the benefit of the doubt. Nothing is for certain, and so to make a leap into the unknown, to challenge centuries of knowledge and billions of people, should be seen not as ignorance but bravery.

title: Whistleblowers Make More Claims About Secret Pentagon UFO Data Retrieval Program
description: Numerous people with ties to the United States government have claimed that the Pentagon has been running secret programs tasked with retrieving UFOs and ...
article_content:
istockphoto composite

Numerous people with ties to the United States government have claimed that the Pentagon has been running secret programs tasked with retrieving UFOs and aliens.

None of them, of course, have ever been able to prove with 100 percent certainty that they exist, but there have been some pretty knowledgeable and high-ranking people behind those claims.

Among those who have come forward over the past few years about what the U.S. government has been hiding when it comes to UFOs are former director of the Department of Defense’s (DoD) Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force, Jay Stratton; veteran of the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO), David Grusch; investigator for the Pentagon’s Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP), Luis Elizondo; Eric W. Davis, an astrophysicist who worked as a subcontractor and then a consultant for the Pentagon UFO program; Harald Malmgren, who served as a senior adviser under four Presidents; and the late former Democratic majority leader in the Senate, Harry Reid.

Now, a new report by the Daily Mail adds another layer of intrigue with even more whistleblower testimony.

According to these whistleblowers, there has been a secret Pentagon UFO data retrieval program that has been hidden from Congressional oversight since 2017.

Codenamed “Immaculate Constellation,” the directive of the program is to “detect” and “quarantine” the military’s best UFO imagery, as well as its best videos, eyewitness testimonies and electronic sensor evidence.

This trove of high quality, multi-sensor UFO data is so tightly held that ‘talking about it will put you in the danger zone,’ according to a US official who confirmed the leak. The quite literally ‘above top secret’ program allegedly sprang into action in the wake of the 2017 leak of three, still-as-yet unexplained US Navy infrared UFO videos.

If true, this program will have been operating outside the law as any type of Special Access Program, or SAP, must be disclosed. According to the whistleblowers, the secret Pentagon UFO data retrieval program is what is known, according to the source, as an “Unacknowledged Special Access Program,” or USAP.

This would help explain why a Pentagon spokesperson denied the existence of the program, claiming, “The Department of Defense has no record, present or historical, of any type of SAP [Special Access Program] called ‘Immaculate Constellation.'”

“The Executive Branch has been managing UAP/NHI issues without Congressional knowledge, oversight, or authorization for some time, quite possibly decades,” the whistleblower wrote in a report they say was presented to Congress and shared with the website Public.

A second whistleblower added that this UFO data retrieval program “is run out of SEC DEF [Office of the Secretary of Defense].”

Last year, Tennessee Congressman Tim Burchett accused the United States government of a “huge cover-up” when it comes to revealing what it knows about UFOs and aliens.

In 2020, former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid admitted that he spearheaded two programs funded by a Congressional “black budget” and were run through a company called Bigelow Aerospace Advanced Space Studies, which worked alongside the Pentagon.

title: Can Adobe repair its AI reputation with its new Content Authenticity web app?
description: The company has announced a new Content Authenticity Web App designed to "champion creator protection and attribution". An ...
article_content:
When you buy through links on our articles, Future and its syndication partners may earn a commission.

Credit: Adobe/Future

Several companies have experienced reputational issues as a result of their approach to AI in 2024. Chief among them is Adobe, whose Terms of Service debacle in the summer led to a fierce backlash from creatives. But the brand's latest move might just help ingratiate the company with AI-sceptics.

The company has announced a new Content Authenticity Web App designed to "champion creator protection and attribution". An extension of the Content Authenticity Initiative we've already seen Adobe develop over the last couple of years, the new web app offers a free way for creators to apply content credentials to their work.

Adobe

As well as adding credentials, the web app lets creators set AI training and usage preferences, essentially letting artists opt-out of being trained by models. Of course, this relies on other models recognising this, but Adobe is "actively working to drive industry-wide adoption of this preference."

A free, public beta of the Adobe Content Authenticity web app will be available in Q1 2025, and users can sign up for more information here. As well as the web app, there'll also be a handy Chrome extension for inspecting credentials.

Adobe Content Credentials web app

"Adobe’s new tool for signing artwork is a game-changer," gushes illustrator Pepita Sandwich via the Adobe website. "It makes adding Content Credentials to digital pieces easy and professional. The interface is intuitive and ensures seamless integration, while the security features give me peace of mind. I also love that it offers the option to opt-out of AI training—perfect for protecting my creative rights."

It's certainly a timely move for a company that has endured its fair share of criticism from artists this year, as well as facing the small matter of getting sued by the US government over its convoluted cancellation processes. But with the brand having previously committed to "doing the right thing" when it comes to AI, focussing its efforts on the Content Authenticity Initiative seems like a wise move.

title: Strange Possessions haunted exhibit opens through Laredo Paranormal Research Society, NeverDead Entertainment partnership
description: Uncover Laredo's haunted history at the Strange Possessions Exhibit, showcasing eerie relics and captivating stories at the ...
article_content:
Emma, the haunted antique doll, sits inside a box that will display her at the Strange Possessions Exhibit on Oct. 11. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

The Border Heritage Museum is partnering with NeverDead Entertainment and the Laredo Paranormal Research Society to publicly showcase local haunted artifacts for the first time.

For a little over three weeks, the museum will host the Strange Possessions Exhibit, which will house 20 relics with haunting backstories. The exhibit officially opened Friday at the Villa Antigua Border Heritage Museum, located at 810 Zaragoza St.

The Strange Possessions Exhibit opens Friday, showcasing "haunted artifacts" at the Border Heritage Museum through a partnership with NeverDead Entertainment and the Laredo Paranormal Research Society. Courtesy/Laredo Paranormal Research Society

NeverDead Entertainment founder Jesus Moreno says Laredo Paranormal Research Society founder Ismael Cuellar agreed to lend the relics from a collection of more than 200 items, which some believe to be cursed or possessed, that the society gathered over 30 years.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

“The paranormal, or stories of the paranormal, is such a huge part of our culture. These items even more so because they’re taken from homes here in Laredo,” Moreno said. “Some of these are from the historic Saint Peter’s area or other historic homes in Laredo.”

Cuellar said all except one item publicly debuted on Friday. The LPRS's well-known item, Emma — a plastic hillside doll with counter-weight eyes in a Victorian-era baby’s gown and hood — is making another appearance.

The doll came into the LPRS's possession in 2006 after an antique doll and curiosity collector complained of unexplained noises and occurrences in their home. After the society conducted an investigation, the LPRS said Emma appeared to blink and close its left eye after sitting in an isolated room for more than 40 hours.

Cuellar said he has presented Emma in public, with the LPRS later being asked to no longer bring her due to reports of flickering lights and strange sounds when she was present.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Raggedy Andy, the possessed doll who doesn't enjoy being separate from its counterpart, Raggedy Ann. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

Raggedy Ann, the possessed doll who doesn't enjoy being separate from its counterpart, Raggedy Andy. Courtesy/Jorge Vasquez

Other items include a presumed witchcraft box that was found under a Laredo home, picture frames that are said to fly off the walls, and a pair of cloth Raggedy Ann and Andy dolls that reportedly refuse to be separated.

“Every time the family would leave the house, they would be in different areas of the house,” Cuellar said of the two dolls. “They separated the dolls, and then the following night, they found the dolls together. That was a big scare.”

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Each artifact on display will showcase its background and the local stories or history that connect it to the area.

“The stories are very, very unique,” Cuellar said.

Pictured is the Border Heritage Museum, located at 810 Zaragoza St. in Laredo, Texas in 2023. Courtesy/WCHF

Moreno said that being able to display these items is an honor. “For (Cuellar) to trust us in displaying these artifacts and sharing the history, it’s a huge honor,” Moreno said. “Ultimately, it’s the point of research. We want to share what we found. We want to share the information we have available to us for future generations.”

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

NeverDead Entertainment and LPRS politely ask attendees to avoid touching the artifacts on display in order to preserve them and offer caution when being around Emma.

“Emma is the exception,” Moreno said. “There are extra precautions. She’s kept in a separate area.

“As long as people follow (the rules) and are safe about it, there shouldn’t be much of a problem or a danger for someone who wants to see the exhibit. But hey, if you’re religious or have any sort of belief, it doesn’t hurt to say a prayer before and after.”

title: Kindred 'spirits': for Joanna MacGugan, bonds of friendship in paranormal investigations
description: Joanna MacGugan is a social historian, copy editor, and paranormal investigator. She is currently writing a history of the ...
article_content:
Joanna MacGugan

Special to Worcester Magazine

Imagine sitting in the dark in a tiny, shabby cabin where enslaved people once prepared meals for the residents of the mansion next door. It’s after midnight. You’ve scattered video cameras around the cabin. You ask questions about the lives of those who labored here, and you hope that you’ve captured their answers on your audio recorders. You glance down a short passageway and watch, saucer eyed, as a video camera launches itself off a wicker chair for no discernible reason.

Once you recover from your shock, you try to recreate and debunk it. You can’t. Could it possibly be something paranormal?

Experiences like this often lead me to reflect on the unexpected turns life can take. Sometimes you land someplace completely weird, and you find a sense of belonging you never expected. After 15 years of training as a historian, I assumed a traditional teaching job would be waiting for me after graduation. Instead, I’m investigating reportedly haunted houses and writing about them. Looking back, the leap from scholar to paranormal investigator might not be as strange as it seems because I investigate to better understand history.

More:Connell Sanders: Mama loves to rock, and baby's along for the big noise

More:Last Call: Historian looks for clues to life, death and justice in medieval Ireland

Even when we can’t verify something we learn from an investigation as historical truth, the story becomes an important part of the haunted location’s lore. And when the historical record matches up with our paranormal experiences, we’ve struck gold.

I’ve found my favorite people in the paranormal community. We share more than a love for all things spooky; we’re connected by curiosity and a desire to tell the stories of those who have passed. We bond over experiences that nobody else would understand.

We also support each other’s creative pursuits; we are writers, photographers, filmmakers and musicians. And the best paranormal conventions (or paracons) feel more like family reunions than your ordinary geeky gatherings. There’s the darker side of the paranormal community, too — the big egos, fame-seekers and petty drama. But it’s easy enough to look past them and find the people you want on your team. I’ve joined countless paranormal investigations in the U.S. and the U.K., and I’ve met kindred spirits who are now lifelong friends.

When we investigate haunted places, we protect each other. We learn our teammates’ body language, and we recognize when they’re uncomfortable and need to leave the scene. Our camaraderie often dispels tension in places where traumatic events happened.

Sometimes we catch the best electric voice phenomena (also known as EVPs; unexplained voices imprinted on audio recordings) when we’re relaxed and trading lighthearted banter — the kind that comes from people who genuinely like each other. There’s no judgment. We understand each other, and we know that our experiences are real. We don’t really care if other people might think we’re bonkers.

“Community” means something different for everyone. Since I found mine, I’ve learned what it feels like to let my guard down and embrace the weird, because we’re all weirdos at heart. If hanging out in haunted places after dark and hoping for an experience you can’t explain is your idea of a good time, come celebrate the weird with us. You’re always going to be welcome in the paranormal community.

Joanna MacGugan is a social historian, copy editor, and paranormal investigator. She is currently writing a history of the Peter Oliver House in Middleborough.

title: Nobel-winning AI was built on open science. Will the quest for profits quash collaboration?
description: The chemistry prize shows the power of collective research, freely shared. Now some worry data access will be restricted as ...
article_content:
The 2024 Nobel Prizes will be remembered as the year that artificial intelligence took the awards by storm. The physics prize this week was awarded to two scientists, John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton, who laid the groundwork for the field of machine learning. The next day, the chemistry prize went to a trio of researchers whose work built on Hopfield and Hinton’s principles, developing AI models that predict the structure of proteins and design entirely new ones.

Structural biologists have hailed the AI work of the chemistry laureates — David Baker of the University of Washington, and Demis Hassabis and John Jumper at Alphabet-owned DeepMind — as sensational discoveries driving major change in drug discovery and fundamental biology research. But to that scientific community, the chemistry prize is also a sign of the power of collective research, freely shared.

advertisement

Now that these efforts have yielded fruit ripe for commercialization, though, the open spirit that’s allowed that scientific progress may be in jeopardy as companies begin to pull back on what they share publicly.

title: Pioneering innovations in quantum devices and algorithms for chemical science
description: Science X is a network of high quality websites with most complete and comprehensive daily coverage of the full sweep of ...
article_content:
Researchers at Harvard University use a model Hamiltonian to simulate strongly-correlated matter in quantum systems. Credit: Nishad Maskara et al. / Harvard University

Since its founding in 2020, the Quantum Systems Accelerator (QSA) has advanced the science and technologies required to bridge the gap between today's NISQ (Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum) information systems and those that will be fully fault-tolerant to facilitate impactful scientific discovery.

As a U.S. National Quantum Information Science Research Center, QSA has developed algorithms and applications constructed explicitly for the current near-term, imperfect quantum systems to advance fundamental research across various fields such as chemical science.

Programmable quantum computers have the potential to efficiently simulate increasingly complex molecular structures, electronic structures, chemical reactions, and quantum mechanical states in chemistry that classical computers cannot.

As the molecule's size and complexity increase, so do the computational resources required to model it. For example, it could take thousands to millions of years, even with the world's most advanced classical supercomputers, to simulate essential molecules for drug discovery.

Indeed, chemistry has emerged as one of the most compelling applications of near-term quantum devices. Given their ability to process information in qubits, quantum processors are naturally suited for simulating the dynamics of complex and highly correlated quantum systems.

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is a key structural characterization technique in biology, chemistry, and materials science that gathers structural information about atoms and their arrangement in space. However, interpreting the results can be challenging. This is especially true for zero-field NMR experiments which remove the large magnet used in conventional NMR experiments.

The quantum simulation of NMR, however, enables the possibility of mimicking the noisy dynamics of one system with the dynamics of another.

An interdisciplinary collaboration by QSA researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Harvard University, University of Maryland, and Duke University demonstrated a zero-field NMR digital quantum simulation experiment on a programmable trapped-ion processor. Their 2023 study was published in the journal Science Advances.

The team used four qubits to compute the zero-field NMR spectrum of the methyl group of acetonitrile for the first time, a simple organic compound used in many products, including pharmaceuticals, pesticides, plastics, and batteries. Furthermore, researchers deployed compressed sensing techniques to obtain accurate results in less time and with less computational resources.

This novel experimental work paves the way for finding exciting practical uses of near-term quantum devices.

"Tailoring the algorithmic and hardware approaches to the structure of NMR systems may enable resource-efficient simulations on near-term devices, thereby opening specific biochemistry analysis pipelines. The breadth and depth of the QSA community provide a fertile ground for the multidisciplinary collaborative efforts required to realize the potential of this application," said Kushal Seetharam, postdoctoral fellow at Harvard University and lead paper author.

QSA, in parallel, is further developing quantum devices based on arrays of neutral atoms with pioneering methods for control and fast readout for complex molecular simulations. A multi-institution team led by QSA researchers at Harvard University published a theoretical framework for simulating strongly correlated quantum systems in chemistry using Rydberg atom arrays.

The authors published their study last December on the arXiv preprint server, offering a flexible quantum toolbox for simulating the time evolution of spin Hamiltonians (mathematical models of quantum systems).

Using a mix of computational approaches and engineering methods, including hardware-specific multi-qubit gates for the Rydberg atom arrays, researchers showed how to optimize hardware operations to accurately simulate complex interactions between spins.

Using hybrid quantum-classical computing techniques, they also introduced an algorithm from near-term quantum experiments, enabling predictions of key quantities, such as how energy and temperature changes could influence the chemical properties and behavior of molecules and atoms.

"Neutral atom arrays have undergone rapid experimental progress in recent years, and here, we show how these novel architectures can be applied to accelerate classically challenging simulations of quantum systems. The collaborations facilitated by the QSA are crucial for pursuing this interdisciplinary research," explained Nishad Maskara, Ph.D. researcher at Harvard and lead paper author.

Researchers further suggested that this framework could study exotic materials, such as transition metal compounds with complex magnetic properties. These compounds appear in various contexts, including catalysis in biological systems. Further, simulations of 2D or 3D transition metal materials could provide clues to some of the fabrication and material challenges of quantum processors currently using conventional materials.

"The ability to perform detailed and accurate quantum simulations will be invaluable for chemists and material scientists as they try to understand experimental results and design new compounds with interesting properties," said Maskara.

Computational simulation in classical computers has been limited by the exponentially large number of possible state configurations required to interpret the nuclear spin system for large molecules, proteins, and protocols. Therefore, complex simulations in chemical science are ideal for tackling with a quantum computer.

Through collaboration, QSA continues to drive innovation in quantum prototypes and algorithms for fundamental science, especially complex chemistry, across all partner institutions. Harvard researchers are currently exploring how to advance the quantum simulation of the NMR experiment with a toolbox of protocols using reconfigurable quantum processors.

"Guided by a science-first approach since 2020, QSA has developed scalable quantum systems and prototypes that will pave the way for groundbreaking discoveries across various hardware platforms, algorithms, and science applications," said Sandia National Laboratories' Daniel Stick, QSA's Deputy Director.

Provided by Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

title: Rogers to Launch Warner Bros. Discovery Channels in Canada
description: Rogers Communications confirmed that it will become the exclusive home of Warner Bros. Discovery’s suite of English-language ...
article_content:
Rogers Communications confirmed that it will become the exclusive home of Warner Bros. Discovery’s suite of English-language U.S. lifestyle and factual brands starting January 1, 2025.

This announcement highlights Rogers' commitment to bringing this sought-after content to Canadians, especially following Bell’s decision to abandon its legal efforts to prevent Canadian viewers from accessing Discovery channels.

As the exclusive English-language content rights holder, distributor, and advertising representative for the Discovery brands in Canada, Rogers plans to launch dedicated TV channels for Discovery ID and Discovery. Additionally, the content from Cooking, OWN, MotorTrend, Animal Planet, and Discovery Science will be available on demand and through Citytv+ on Amazon Prime Video Channels.

Earlier in June, Bell filed a Notice of Application in the Ontario Superior Court seeking an injunction to block Rogers from distributing Discovery channels. However, Bell later acknowledged that all claims against Rogers were unfounded and subsequently abandoned its legal efforts.

title: Accelerating Change: How No-Code Shapes Digital Transformation
description: Discover how no-code platforms are revolutionizing digital transformation, enabling faster innovation, agility, and seamless ...
article_content:
>>

>>

>>

IT SERVICE

If your business is attempting to stay ahead of the technology curve, you know your goal is to radically optimize how your business operates and engages with customers using new and cutting-edge technologies.

But instead of the usual lengthy and technical development cycles, you have a secret weapon that simplifies and accelerates this transformation—no-code technology.

In this article, we’ll show you how utilizing no-code platforms with tools like codeless app design and WYSIWYG app builders can redefine your approach to digital innovation.

Streamlining Development with Codeless App Design

In your journey toward digital transformation, the ability to quickly adapt and implement new technologies stands paramount. No-code platforms, equipped with codeless app design capabilities, empower your team to create and deploy apps without writing a single line of code.

This means that even team members who aren't traditionally tech-savvy can contribute to the app development process, significantly speeding up project timelines.

Imagine you're tasked with improving customer engagement through a new interactive app. With a codeless app design tool, you can drag and drop elements to assemble a prototype within hours, not weeks. This rapid prototyping accelerates development and allows for iterative testing and feedback, ensuring the final product meets user needs while aligning with your strategic goals.

Optimal Flexibility with WYSIWYG App Builders

A crucial element of digital transformation is flexibility—the ability to pivot and tailor solutions in real-time as your business needs evolve. What You See Is What You Get, or WYSIWYG app builders, exemplify this flexibility. They allow you to build and edit your applications visually, seeing exactly how they'll appear to the end-users as you construct them.

This hands-on approach reduces misunderstandings and miscommunications between business departments and IT teams. For example, your marketing team can directly create landing pages and promotional apps, ensuring that the end design matches their vision without back-and-forth with developers.

This saves time and empowers your non-technical staff to execute their ideas independently.

Reducing Costs and Resource Allocation

One significant impact of no-code in your digital transformation strategy is cost reduction. Traditional app development involves significant investment in technical staff, extended development timelines, and often expensive fixes and iterations.

No-code platforms change this dynamic by minimizing the need for a large development team and reducing the dependency on external IT consultants or software development companies.

Integrating no-code tools into your strategy allows you to allocate your financial and human resources more efficiently. Savings on technical development can be redirected towards other critical areas, such as market research, customer experience improvements, or expansion strategies.

Moreover, the ease of updating applications built with no-code tools means that maintaining and improving your digital assets becomes less costly and more manageable over time.

Driving Business Agility and Competitive Advantage

No-code platforms give your business the agility to stay ahead of the curve. Because no-code development significantly shortens the time from concept to deployment, your business can respond more swiftly to market changes and emerging opportunities.

Additionally, no-code tools give you the competitive advantage of experimenting with and implementing new ideas quickly without substantial upfront investment.

Whether it's testing a new customer service bot, a unique booking system, or a custom data analysis tool, no-code platforms let you innovate faster, learn quickly from real-world feedback, and iterate effectively.

Integrating no-code technology into your strategy offers a pathway to more than just technological advancement. It transforms your organizational culture. It democratizes technology creation, empowers your teams, and sprinkles both agility and innovation into your business.

Using no-code platforms is a no-brainer. They can dismantle traditional barriers to technology development, open up new avenues for growth, and position your business as a leader in the digital economy.

title: Deals: Galaxy Tab S9 $180+ off, Galaxy Watch Ultra drops again, Bose Ultra Headphones $150 off, more
description: Friday’s best deals are headlined by a significant price drop on the base model Samsung Galaxy Tab S9 at $387 under the most ...
article_content:
Friday’s best deals are headlined by a significant price drop on the base model Samsung Galaxy Tab S9 at $387 under the most affordable S10 and now sitting at one of the lowest prices we have ever tracked. But the Samsung deals keep coming as not only is the best price ever still live on the Galaxy Buds 3 Pro at nearly $100 off, but the Galaxy Watch Ultra has somehow now dropped down even lower than the $100 deals we spotted for Prime Day. From there, we have the regularly $429 Bose QuietComfort Ultra Headphones starting from $279 alongside some Google Home gear, chargers, speakers, and more. Scope it all out down below.

Samsung’s Galaxy Tab S9 now $387 under the most affordable S10 starting at $613 (Reg. $800)

The new plus and Ultra model Tab S10 have arrived, but Amazon is landing with a serious deal on the Samsung Galaxy Tab S9 in graphite at $612.49 shipped. This is a regularly $800 tablet that effectively remains the current-generation base-model flagship release – there its no standard S10 just yet. This model is still sold on the official Samsung storefront and currently for the full $800 MSRP. You can score up to $600 instant trade credit there, but Amazon is now offering one of the best straight up cash deals we have tracked with $187 in savings – this is well under the $650 we featured last month.

Best price ever somehow still live: Samsung’s Galaxy Buds 3 Pro still at wild $152 all-time low (Nearly $100 off with no trade in needed)

Update: This deal is still live (somehow) and now with no code needed.

In a frankly wild turn of events, although it shouldn’t be all that surprising considering how aggressive Woot has been as of late on recently released tech, the Amazon retailer is now undercutting everyone on the new Galaxy Buds 3 Pro. The regularly $250 set of flagship earbuds dropped (and remains) and its best post-release price to date over at Amazon with a $209.99 discounted listing, but using code SAVE20 at checkout over on Woot today, you can score a set at a surprisingly notable $151.99 Prime shipped (a $6 delivery fee will apply otherwise). That’s nearly $100 off, close to $70 under Amazon’s Prime Day price, and the best we have ever tracked. Woot ships with a full 1-year warranty from Samsung too.

Regularly $429 Bose QuietComfort Ultra ANC Headphones drop to $279 today

We caught a solid $100 price drop on the wonderful Bose QuietComfort Ultra Headphones in new condition for Prime Day this year – a notable offer for sure. But the official Bose site and its wonderful refurbishment program is now offering them down at $279 shipped. This is a $429 pair of active noise cancellation headphones (among the very best in fact) now seeing a sizable $150 price drop. Bose runs one of the better refurbished programs in the game and ships these headphones with the same warranty as a new set.

Samsung Galaxy Watch Ultra now sitting below Prime Day price at nearly $118 off with new lows from $532

Update: Prices have now dropped again to new all-time lows at Amazon across all colorways.

We have been seeing some seriously notable deals on the new Samsung Galaxy Watch Ultra over the last week or so, but Amazon has now dropped the price down even lower across the lineup. Now starting from $532.20 shipped on the Titanium Gray model with the orange band, all three configurations on Amazon are now at new all-time lows with the Titanium Silver and gray band combo at $549.99 and the Titanium White model with the white band at $532.20 shipped. Now sitting at up to $109.50 off the sticker price, all three options are now at new all-time lows and undercutting the Prime Day prices we were tracking over the last couple days.

TP-Link’s Google Home magnetic wireless smart cam has FREE AI motion detection, now back at $60 (Reg. $90+)

Update: This deal is live once again. Details in original post below.

Amazon is now offering its best price yet on the TP-Link Tapo Smart MagCam (C425) at $59.99 shipped after you clip the on-page coupon. This wireless smart camera hit Amazon for the first time in late 2023 at $120 before more typically fetching a $90 price tag through 2024. Today’s offer knocked that price down even further with a straight markdown to $80 and an additional $20 in savings via the coupon code. This is the lowest price we have tracked on Amazon since release.

Today’s accessories and charging deals:

Samsung’s Galaxy Tab S9 FE 256GB just hit the $380 Amazon all-time low ($140 off)

Today we are tracking one of the best prices ever on the Samsung Galaxy Tab S9 FE with the upgraded 256GB of storage. We did see the entry 128GB model drop to $333 last month, but Amazon just knocked the regularly $520 upgraded configuration to $379.99 shipped. While only on the silver model – my personal favorite of the bunch, we haven’t seen a price anywhere near this since mid July and even then it never dropped below $389. Today’s deal is a new Amazon low on this configuration at $20 under the price we saw over the last two days for the fall Prime event.

The new Ticwatch 5 Enduro model has now returned to its best price yet. After being unleashed this past May as an updated version of the existing model, the official Mobvoi Amazon store is serving up an on-page coupon once again to knock the price on the Wear OS Ticwatch Pro 5 Enduro Smartwatch down to $261.99 shipped. Regularly $350, you’ll find this deal live on both the Obsidian and Slate colorways. Today’s offer is matching our previous mention to land at the lowest price we have tracked for the second time since release.

Anker’s new 14-port Anker Prime Docking Station now $5 under Prime Day low at $175 (Reg. $250), more

One of our top 10 Prime Day deals was the 2024 Anker Prime lineup, featuring a series of charging solutions and the 14-port Anker Prime Docking Station. This regularly $250 USB-C/A hub fell to $212.49 before dropping again to $180 for day 2 of the Amazon fall event, and now it is sitting at the $174.99 shipped all-time low. There’s no telling how long this straight up 30% price drop will stick around for considering it is in some ways a hangover Prime Day deal, so you’ll want to jump as soon as possible if you’re interested.

Subscribe to the 9to5Toys YouTube Channel for all of the latest videos, reviews, and more!

title: Saudi Arabia $19+ Mn Deck Software Market Trends, Competition, Forecast & Opportunities, 2029F
description: The "Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market, By Region, Competition, Forecast & Opportunities, 2019-2029F" report has been added ...
article_content:
Company Logo

Saudi Arabian Deck Software Market

Saudi Arabian Deck Software Market

Dublin, Oct. 11, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The "Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market, By Region, Competition, Forecast & Opportunities, 2019-2029F" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.



Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market was valued at USD 10.5 million in 2023 and is expected to reach at USD 19.1 Million in 2029 and project robust growth in the forecast period with a CAGR of 10.4% through 2029

The Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market is experiencing significant growth, driven by the country's robust expansion in construction and real estate sectors. Deck software, essential for designing and planning deck structures, is increasingly adopted by architects, builders, and remodeling professionals in Saudi Arabia.

The market's expansion is fueled by the growing need for sophisticated design tools that streamline the planning process, ensure structural integrity, and enhance visual appeal. Innovations in software features, including advanced 3D modeling, real-time rendering, and integration with Building Information Modeling (BIM), are attracting a diverse clientele.

Additionally, the rise in residential and commercial construction projects across the kingdom is propelling demand for efficient and user-friendly deck design solutions. The government's focus on infrastructure development and urbanization further supports market growth, positioning Saudi Arabia as a pivotal player in the regional deck software landscape. As the market evolves, opportunities for advanced technological integrations and tailored solutions for local building standards are expected to drive continued expansion.



Technological advancements are a significant driver in the Saudi Arabian deck software market. Innovations such as advanced 3D modeling, augmented reality (AR), and integration with Building Information Modeling (BIM) systems are transforming how deck designs are created and managed. These technologies provide architects and builders with powerful tools to visualize complex structures, streamline design processes, and improve project outcomes. The adoption of these advanced features enhances the accuracy and efficiency of deck planning, making it easier to meet the evolving demands of the construction industry. As software developers continue to integrate new technologies and functionalities, the appeal and utility of deck software in Saudi Arabia's competitive market are expected to grow.



One of the primary challenges in the Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market is the high cost associated with advanced software solutions. Deck software often incorporates sophisticated features such as 3D modeling, simulation, and integration with other building systems, which can be expensive. For small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and emerging firms, these costs can be a significant barrier to adoption. The financial investment required for acquiring licenses, maintaining updates, and training personnel can be substantial, leading to budget constraints and reluctance to invest in high-end software. This challenge is exacerbated by the need for continuous upgrades to keep pace with technological advancements and industry standards. The high cost of advanced solutions can limit access for smaller firms and reduce overall market penetration, impacting the widespread adoption of deck software in the region.

Key Attributes:





Report Attribute Details No. of Pages 86 Forecast Period 2023 - 2029 Estimated Market Value (USD) in 2023 $10.5 Million Forecasted Market Value (USD) by 2029 $19.1 Million Compound Annual Growth Rate 10.4% Regions Covered Saudi Arabia



Segmental Insights

Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market Application Insights

Commercial Application Segment:

Dominated the Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market in 2023, driven by strong demand for advanced design solutions in the construction and real estate sectors.

Key commercial projects (office buildings, retail spaces, public infrastructure) require sophisticated deck software to manage complex design needs, ensure regulatory compliance, and optimize materials and costs.

The sector prioritizes features like detailed structural analysis, integration with design tools, and handling extensive data.

High-quality construction and efficient project management in commercial developments are further boosting the adoption of specialized deck software.

As commercial construction and infrastructure projects continue to grow in Saudi Arabia, the demand for tailored deck software is expected to remain robust.

Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market Deployment Insights

Cloud-Based Deployment Segment:

Predominantly drives the Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market, expected to continue its growth during the forecast period.

Cloud solutions offer scalability, cost-effectiveness, and flexibility compared to on-premise systems, eliminating substantial upfront hardware investments.

Subscription-based pricing leads to lower overall costs and provides enhanced accessibility, crucial for remote teams.

Automatic updates and maintenance ease the burden on IT staff, ensuring access to the latest features and security patches.

The trend aligns with Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 initiative, emphasizing technological advancement and innovation, making cloud-based deck software the preferred choice.

Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market Regional Insights

Riyadh Region:

Emerged as the dominant force in the Saudi Arabia Deck Software Market, projected to maintain its leadership throughout the forecast period.

As the capital and largest city, Riyadh is a central hub for economic and infrastructural development, driving demand for advanced deck software.

Rapid urbanization and significant investments in commercial and residential projects necessitate sophisticated design and planning solutions.

The city attracts local and international developers, further fueling demand for cutting-edge deck software.

Ongoing development projects and the adoption of technology in construction reinforce Riyadh's leading status in the market.

Oliver Rodzianko is an investment analyst specializing in the technology sector, with a focus on artificial intelligence, semiconductors, software, and renewable energy. He has earned a strong reputation on Seeking Alpha, where he is frequently featured in the platform’s "Must Reads." His work is also syndicated by GuruFocus to Forbes, expanding his visibility in the financial community. Oliver also occasionally writes for TipRanks, where he delivers deep, high-quality analysis for advanced readers. His research expertise combines traditional fundamental analysis with advanced proprietary data tools, with an investment philosophy rooted in value and growth-at-a-reasonable-price strategies. Increasingly, he focuses on small-cap and micro-cap companies. Oliver manages a private investment portfolio, prioritizing high-quality, undervalued businesses with sustainable growth potential and ethical business practices.
